unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Swordfish Growth Rates
question_text:
A marine biologist was interested in the average annual growth rate of swordfish.
A sampling of $16\text{ tagged swordfish}$ found a mean growth rate of $1.4\text{ feet}$ with a standard deviation of $0.23\text{ feet}$. The confidence interval estimated the true mean growth rate is most likely somewhere between $1.2306$ and $1.5694\text{ feet}$.
The given interval has what level of confidence?
solution:
The margin of error will be half the width of a confidence interval:

$$1.5694-1.2306 = 0.3388$$

$$\dfrac{0.3388}{2} = 0.1694$$

This margin of error should be equal to:

$$t\cdot \left[\dfrac{\text{standard deviation}}{\sqrt{n}}\right]$$

All information is known except for $t$, so we use the equation above to solve for $t$, where $\text{margin of error} = 0.1694$, $n = 16$, and $s = 0.23$.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.

Solve to find $t = 2.947$.

With sample size $n = 16$, at $15$ degrees of freedom, only an interval of $99\%$ confidence gives a $t$-value of $2.947$ using the $T$-distribution table.
